FacilityName: Omaha Public Power Nebraska City Power Station

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Omaha Public Power District's (OPPD) Nebraska City Station is a coal-fired electric generating facility. It is located 5 miles south of Nebraska City in Otoe County, Nebraska.  Nebraska City Station's Unit 2 uses anhydrous ammonia in the operation of its selective catalytic reduction (SCR) pollution prevention system. Anhydrous ammonia is the only Risk Management Program (RMP) listed chemical that is present at Nebraska City Station above the threshold quantity.



The anhydrous ammonia process at Nebraska City Station is not eligible for Program Level 1 because the distance to a toxic endpoint for the worst-case release assessment is greater than the distance to any public receptor (40 CFR 68.10(b)(2)). The anhydrous ammonia process is not required to be a Program Level 3 because the process is in NAICS code 221112, fossil fuel electric power generation, and not in one of the ten NAICS codes listed in 40 CFR 68.10(b)(1). The process is also not subject to the OSHA process safety management standard (40 CFR 68.10(b)(2)), because  OPPD is a political subdivision of the State of Nebraska, and Nebraska does not have a state OSHA program.  Therefore, the applicable Program Level for the anhydrous ammonia process at Nebraska City Station is Program Level 2.



The original Risk Management Plan for Nebraska City Station was submitted to EPA at the time a second electric generating unit, Unit 2, was being added to the facility. The anhydrous ammonia was brought on-site for the operation of Unit 2's selective catalytic reduction (SCR) pollution prevention system.  Because the SCR system was installed by contractors, and the contractors were subject to OSHA rules, OPPD decided that the RMP Program Level of the anhydrous ammonia process would be a Program Level 3, as a conservative measure. Since completion of the construction of the SCR system, the system has been operated and maintained by OPPD employees, who are not subj

ect to OSHA rules. For this reason, OPPD has determined that keeping the anhydrous ammonia process at a Program 3 level is not necessary, and OPPD is changing the Program Level of the process from a Program Level 3 to a Program Level 2 in this RMP resubmittal.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

OPPD is committed to employee and public safety and the protection of the environment. To demonstrate this commitment, OPPD has invested significant resources in preventing the release of anhydrous ammonia; as is evident in all elements of OPPD's prevention program.  As an example, OPPD requires all employees, contractors, vendors, and unescorted visitors to take general ammonia awareness training.



Overall safety at Nebraska City Station is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases that may occur. OPPD has developed a robust emergency response program which includes having a trained Hazardous Material Response Team on-site and coordinating emergency response with the local emergency response agency. 



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

OPPD's Program 2 Prevention Program for the anhydrous ammonia system is a rigorous program which was designed to meet the requirements of the RMP regulations. 



OPPD updated and revalidated its hazard review on 12/28/2012. The review examined the hazards associated with the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) process and the use of anhydrous ammonia. It also assessed the possibilites of equipment malfunction and/or human errors that could cause an accidental release. Safeguards used or needed to control the hazards or prevent equipment malfunction or human error were evaluated. The review process also included the review of steps used or needed to detect or monitor releases. 



In addition to the hazard review, OPPD's Program 2 Prevention Progra

m incorporates all of the required elements, including:



Operating Procedures: OPPD has developed written operating procedures for the safe storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia at Nebraska City Station. The procedures specify steps for each operating phase of the process and operating limits (e.g., pressure in the tanks). OPPD has outlined appropriate safety and health considerations and incorporated them into the safe operating procedures.



Training: OPPD has a training program related to the operation, inspection, and maintenance of the SCR anhydrous ammonia system to ensure safe operation.



Maintenance: OPPD has written procedures for maintaining the process equipment. OPPD has identified inspections and maintenance practices needed to comply with good engineering practices and in accordance with manufacturers' recommendations.



Five-Year Accident History:

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia at the time of this filing.



Emergency Response Program:

OPPD has developed a robust emergency response program and written Emergency Response Plan to minimize the effects of a release of anhydrous ammonia to employees, the public, and the environment. The emergency response program includes having a trained, on-site Hazardous Material Response Team available to respond to releases. OPPD also coordinates emergency response planning with the local emergency response agency.  



In the event of fire, explosion, or release of anhydrous ammonia; alarm systems are activated and emergency response is directed as initial evacuation occurs. Re-entry with personal protective equipment including respiratory protection and monitoring instrumentation is required if the ambient atmosphere ammonia levels exceed specified levels. Both emergency response and emergency medical procedures are documented and stressed during emergency response training on-site.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

OPPD is continually evaluating the hazards of operation

of the anhydrous ammonia system. OPPD recently improved the lighting in the area of the anhydrous ammonia tank to provide better visibility. OPPD plans to replace the existing access/egress ladder at the top of the ammonia tank with regular steps and a handrail. This will improve safety for workers who are accessing or exiting the tank. OPPD is also currently evaluating installing video equipment in the vicinity of the ammonia tank in order for the control room operators to be able to remotely view activity in the tank area. OPPD continues to assess areas in which safety can be improved.
